fish_data.name: Bristol Nosed Cats
fish_data.comment:
In my years of tropical fish keeping, I have kept many different fish. One of my favorite species to keep is the Bristol Nosed Cats. The species of bristol cats that I have kept usually grew to be around 4 inches in size and the males are the ones with the bristols while the females did not have bristols. This is my attempt at documenting some of the conditions that were present in my aquarium while breeding these little cats.

   The water quality was tested with Dr. Wellfish test kits. The ammonia was approximately 0ppm, the nitrate was approximately 0ppm, and the pH was at about 7.6 possibly higher and sometimes lower as low as 6.0. These cats can with stand various types of water quality but mine seemed to have done best when the pH was around 7.6. I am not sure what the hardness of the water was though. The temperature was usually around 72 degrees, though the tank was not heated.

   The main tank was a 20 gallon long, although I have also breed them in a 15 gallon. All the tanks have always had gravel bottoms and usually some floating plants as well as some rooted plants like Anubis. The Anubis seemed to do well under the same conditions as the cats. I only used 1 light bulb in the tank. I usually gave them rock shelters too. I have also found that a piece of bog wood helps but is not necessary for breeding. The cats use the bog wood for gnawing on and do like to hide on or under it. Usually the cats breed on the bottom side of a rock shelter. My rock shelters were basically a flat rock that was laid on either one or two round rocks to form a cave that gave them a hiding place.

    I feed the cats shrimp pellets. This was a high protein diet, and seemed to do well for the adults.

   The number of other fish in the tanks varied from time to time. Often I kept anywhere from 2 females cats and one male to three males and 2 females and several babies and juveniles. At one point there were 80+ babies that I was able to raise to about 1.5 inches and then sell them. It seemed more important to keep the water quality well than the number of fish. Good water quality meant no ammonia or nitrates/nitrites. I also kept guppies in these tanks. However they never bred when guppies were in the tank, or if they did the guppies may have gotten to the babies. I tried keeping them with small Central American cichlids once, but the cichlids are too aggressive and stressed the cats.

    The changing of water usually seemed to be the trigger to them spawning. This must have been because of the sudden change in the water conditions from a lower pH to a higher pH. The spawning usually occurred after water change or after moving fish from one tank to another tank of better water conditions. More often than not when they breed once they mate several times, and sometimes there are multiple females involved. If they are kept well fed they will not harm the young.

    I am not sure why they reproduced so much, they just did. I never tried to make them reproduce, I just hoped and they did. Good water conditions are a must for fish to mate so I guess I must have been doing something right. I'd recommend not keeping them with any other bottom feeders or any large fish. Best bet would be livebearers, schooling fish or any other middle or top level small none aggressive fish.

    Bristol Nosed Cats (Ancistrus T or D?)

  • The cats I kept were sexually dimorphic i.e. they could be easily sexed. The males had the bristols.
  • They were somewhat aggressive towards other males, but I never had them kill each other, at least that I know of.
  • They could withstand just about any pH, but I think the water was acidic.
  • They were egg layers in which the male catfish usually protected the young till they left the nest. Sometimes they eat the eggs.
  • They may eat anything they can catch and fit in their mouth, I fed mine shrimp pellets. They were excellent algae eaters.
  • They grew to about 3.5 to 4.5 inches.
  • I have kept one in a 6 gallon tank, or a trio in a 15 gallon tank, or 4 to 5 in a 20 gallon tank.

fish_data.name: Cichlids
fish_data.comment:
I have keep many different types of cichlids. I like keeping these fish too. I have kept Oscars, Convicts, Firemouths, Port Acaras, Blue Acaras, some small African cichlids that I am not sure what they were, as well as the Texas cichlid, Angel fish, Blue Rams, a Jack Dempsey and possibly several others that I cannot remember. Most of the cichlids I have kept have been from South or Central America.  Although my favorite cichlid is the Oscar,  I usually try to keep Convicts instead as they can live in a smaller tank space. An Oscar will grow to about a foot while my Convicts only grow to about 4 to 5 inches or so.

   When I had my Oscars I raised these fish from about 1.5 inches to about 10 inches in about 2 years. If I were to do it again I'd have gotten a 75 to 90 gallon tank for the pair that I had. I was able to sex them at about 1 year. I was not absolutely sure which was which, but was pretty sure by their behavior that they were a pair.

    While not all cichlids form 'permanant life pair bonds', they do exhibit pairing behavior.  Usually two cichlids of will swim very close to each other.  Often thie rfins will tough and they will pass very close to each other.  They also did head to tail touching. Their pectoral fins would touch, as would they touch tails. Often the tail fin of one would touch the body of the other. It is always pretty interesting to watch. They acted almost civil to each other at times because they seemed to like 'touching' each other. They did do some jaw locking as is seen in some other cichlids, but it was more like kissing of sorts. It was not until I actually saw them laying their eggs that I realized that I was right about which was the male and which was the female. They would lay their eggs on the bottom side of a flower pot that was out in the open. Although the eggs hatched I was never able to raise the young. I had the same problem with my Blue Rams when they laid their eggs.

  Convicts seemed to like to breed in an open space. They usually made good parents if they did not eat their young. I have also kept and breed Firemouths. Their behavior was similar to that of the Oscars and Convicts. The main differences that I observed was the Firemouths seamed to prefer to lay their eggs in a cave, typically on the underside of a flat piece of slate rock or on the inside of a flower pot. The second major difference is that they were not as friendly to each other as the Oscars seemed to be. My Convicts seemed to form pair bonds and be somewhat friendly to each other. The Convicts were very aggressive. At one point I had a two female Convicts that exhibited the same behavior as a male/female pair. I referred to them as my lesbian convicts ;-).  I have also heard of stories of angel fish and discus also dispaying lesbian behavior.  Also I have heard of different cichlid species interbreeding.

   The water was anywhere from a pH of 6.0 to 7.8-8.0. The ammonia and nitrates were around 0ppm, and again I never tested the water. The only type of plants I keep were floating plants like water lettuce as anything else was quickly uprooted. I have kept very large pants with my Convicts and Firemouths but these were well established and very large plants.

   Often it was beneficial to separate the pair, with a tank divider, usually a piece of plexi glass prior to breeding. The fish could see each other and water would go between the two halves of the tank. A few days of this and then a water change at the time of removing the divider would usually stimulate the pair to lay eggs. I'd recommend reading about the species that you want to keep and learning about its needs and size requirements. Convicts can be kept with Firemouths and both grow to less than 6 inches.

   Usually I kept species tanks. The only exception is in keeping Convicts with Firemouths. They are fairly compatible if you get them when they are all small fish.

    Convicts ([Cichlasoma/Herichthys]Archocentrus nigrofasciatus)

  • Convicts are sexually dimorphic and usually easy to sex. Females Convicts are more colorful.
  • They are extremely aggressive towards other fish especially when breeding and may kill other fish.
  • They could with stand just about any pH.
  • They are egg layers where both parents raises the young, although they may eat the eggs or young.
  • They may eat anything it can catch and fit in their mouth, I fed them shrimp pellets, color bits, and other slow sinking pellitized foods.
  • Male Convicts grow about 5 inches and females are about 4 inches.  It also depends on the size of the tank that they are kept in and what other fish are in there with them.
  • I'd recommend at least a 10 gallon tank for 2 convicts.
  • Provide LOTS of hiding spaces. The more the better.

    Firemouths ([Cichlasoma]Thorichthys meeki)

  • Firemouths are also sexually dimorphic, they are not that easy to sex. Male Firemouths are usually red bellied while females tend to have more white.
  • They are semi-aggressive towards other fish especially when breeding.
  • They could with stand just about any pH.
  • They are egg layers where both parents raises the young, although they may eat the eggs or young.
  • They may eat anything it can catch and fit in their mouth, I fed them shrimp pellets.
  • Male Firemouths grow about 5 to 5-1/2 inches and females are about 4 to 4-1/2 inches.
  • I'd recommend at least a 15 gallon tank for 2 Firemouths.
  • Provide LOTS of hiding spaces. The more the better.

fish_data.name: Bettas
fish_data.comment:
In my experience, bettas will live for about 2 years.  I have read that they should live for 5 years, however often this is not taking into account a few things.  The first thing to consider is that bettas when bought from a store are probably already 6 months to 2 years old.  The last pet shop I bought my betta from, I decided to ask how old the fish was.  They told me that they were about 1-1/2 years old.  Using that as my estimate for how old the previous onces I got from that shop,  I estimate that one of my bettas died at about 3.5 to 4 years old.  I'd estimate that they lived on average for 1.5 years with me, and the oldest was 2 years old.  Not bad for a 5 dollar fish ( sometimes you can get them cheaper, but I get some pretty nice ones, that I know they are healthy.)

   Bettas grow to about 3 inches, give or take.  There are short fined and long finned varieties.  I usually get the long finned varieties.  But I now own a shortfinned blue male.  He is very vibrant blue.

   I feed them betta bits or other small floating pellitized food.  They seem to do fine with that.  I am going to try to feed them more live or frozen foods, but due to time constraints I find it easier to feed them pellets.

   While it is possible to keep a betta in a small container, which they usually sell them in, I have found that it is better to get a 3 gallon aquarium ( the Eclipse works great ) and get a tank divider and a small heater.  Using this method you can keep 2 bettas in the tank and they will flare up their fins, and display to each other, but wont kill each other.  Also the heater keeps the tank at a temperature above 72 degrees.  While they can survive wihtout the heater, I think that where I live it may get to cold.  I have also noticed that they do better with the heater and they seem to live longer this way as well.  The filter will also make it so that you are not changing their water each week or twice a week.  You can acutally keep some small plants in the tank as well and gravel, and it makes for a nice display tank. 

   To breed bettas a 5 gallon tank will work.  Use lots of floating plants like water lettuce or java moss, or something real bunchy.  Add a male and feed him well.  Keep the water temperature at about 75 to 80 degrees F.  Then when the male starts building a bubble nest add a ripe female.  The female should show dark verticle bands around her middle and she should have a white tube showing on her abdomen.  They pretty much do the rest.    Raising the babies is difficult and requires many containers or a large tank.  They seem to get territorial at an early age. 

   Betta Splendens
  • Sexually dimorphic, males usually have longer fins, females will show dark verticle bands when in breeding condition.
  • Males are extremely aggressive towards their own kind, yet are often preyed upon in a community tank, and will occasionally get their fins nipped.
  • They can handle just about any pH within reason.
  • They are egg layers and the eggs are really small, the male will care for the egs, most of the time.
  • They may eat anything it can catch and fit in their mouth, I fed them small pellets.
  • They grow about 3.5 to 4.5 inches, depending on various conditions.
  • I'd recommend at least a 3 gallon with a divider for 2, or a 2 gallon for a single fish, and a 5 gallon as a breeding tank for a pair.

fish_data.name: Livebearers
fish_data.comment:
I have keep several of the more common live bearer fish. This includes Swordtail's, Guppies, Platies, and Mollies. My favorite is the guppy as I feel it is the most colorful of all these fish with its blues, reds, blacks, greens, orchids, and more colors.

   One thing to note is that pH and temperature has always varied. I think that as long as the pH is somewhere between 6 and 8 most will do just fine and as long as the temperature is not below 68 and not above 90 degrees they will do okay. Nitrates, nitrites, and ammonia should be as close to zero as possible.

   Guppies are very easy to keep and breed, but Platies, Swordtail's, and mollies are fairly easy as well. They are all easy to sex and the fish do all the work. I just feed them ;-). Mollies are a little more difficult than Guppies because Mollies require some salt in the water and the conditions of the water to be a little better. Swordtail's are a little aggressive and can be a little difficult to keep in a community because of this. Lastly some Swordtail's and Mollies can grow to be rather large compared to the Guppies and Platies.

   Sexing guppies is rather easy once they are mature. The males have an extended anal fin (called the gonoponodium) and in the fancy varieties the males are much more colorful than the females.

   The method of breeding I first tried from 1993 to 1999 was selective line breeding. This is when you take a male and mate it with a particular female usually its daughters and granddaughters. In my case I was doing repetitive selective line breeding. I mated males with their daughters and grand daughters. I would select females based on size and the color of the female. For the males I choose them based on their colors, size of the developing tail and size of the fish. This worked out nice, but kept giving me very red males and blue tailed females, even though I was trying for blue males.

   While some people choose to breed one male to two or three females, I was using one male to one female. This would ensure that the female that got pregnant was the female that I wanted and the male that I wanted as well. This went on for several years. Occasionally I would out cross my fish to get some new genes in the pool. This is a good method to create a new variety of guppy, however the drawbacks are that it can weaken the fish, especially the immune system. Many of the fancy male guppies I had ended up having trouble carring their tails as they got older.

   As the fish grow they begin to show various colors. The first color that I always is black on the tail. This of course is in any species that I have kept that have had black in their coloring. The next color is usually yellow and then red. I then see colors like green appear and blue as well. So far it seems that red and black are possibly the dominant color genes and blue is recessive. They did show colors of green shine and blue shine when the light hit them just right, but that was hard to see.

   I have also had some recent success with Platies. I keep red and black Platies and I have had them breed as well. They babies in this species resemble the parents identically, but smaller. Unlike the guppies where the colors appear over time, the Platies show color right away. Mollies are the same, especially the black mollies.

   I've kept different types of livebearers together in the same tank, but usually not for long periods of time. Although I have never had them cross breed (breeding between species) I have heard that it is possible. I'd recommend that in keeping livebearers and mixing them, either keep them all of the same sex or keep both sexes of all the species that you have in the tank.

    Platies(Xiphophorus maculatus or variatus) / Guppies (Poecilia reticulata)

  • Sexually dimorphic, males have gonopodium, which is an extended anal fin.
  • They are not aggressive and can be kept in a community, occasionally they will nip fins of long finned fish or they may get their fins nipped.
  • They could withstand just about any pH.
  • They are live bearers, and may eat their young.
  • They may eat anything it can catch and fit in their mouth, I fed them a shrimp treat flake food.
  • They grow about 1.5 to 4.5 inches, depending on various conditions, and species.
  • I'd recommend at least a 6 gallon for a pair or trio, and a 10 or 20 gallon as a breeding tank for about 6 to 12.

fish_data.name: Rosy Barbs
fish_data.comment:
I have keep Rosy Barbs for a few years. They are pretty hardy fish that remind me of comet goldfish. They are in the same family as goldfish. They can live for a few years, and they are usually pretty active. They are egg scatters, and they usually breed in the morning. They come in albino or gold, rosy red-orange, and long finned varieties. I was actually able to breed these fish pretty easily. In fact they did it on their own before I even tried anything. All I did was harvest the eggs and then hatch them in a different container.
  • Sexually dimorphic, males are usually rosy red and females are usually silver.
  • They are not aggressive and can be kept in a community, occasionally they will nip fins of long finned fish or they may get their fins nipped.
  • They could withstand just about any pH.
  • They are egg scatters and eat their young and eggs.
  • They may eat anything it can catch and fit in their mouth, I fed them slow sinking pellet.
  • They grow about 4 inches, depending on various conditions.
  • I'd recommend at least a 20 gallon for a group of 6.

fish_data.name: White Clouds
fish_data.comment:
I have kept White Cloud Mountain Minnows. They are small fish, about 1.5 inches max. These fish are easy to keep, however I find it best to keep then in a tank that has no gravel or anything on the bottom of the tank. Keeping the tank gravel free allows one to see how much food is not being eaten. I have kept them in a small container that is about a 4 to 5 gallon sized container. Using just a sponge filter they can be kept fairly easily. Water changes can be done twice a week. To breed them I use a small 3 gallon container with 3 spawning mops made out of green acrylic yarn. One mop goes on the bottom the other two are suspended using styrofoam. The tank has a small heater that can raise the temperature 3 or 4 degrees. They seem to breed pretty quickly if the female is round and plump. They will lay lots of eggs and can be removed as soon as some eggs are spotted. The eggs hatch in about 36 hours at about 75 degrees. The fry will become darters about a day after hatching. They should be feed 'green water' for the first few days. After the first week, frozen baby brine shrimp can be feed to the newly hatched fry. Water should be changed every 2 or 3 days in the fry tank depending on how big a tank is used and how many fry are in there, however the environment should not be sterile. The fry will eat microbes and bugs that are in the tank. Fry grow better if they have constant food and live food and clean water. Greenish water or even water that has green water dumped into it in small doses will have lots of little microbes for the fry to eat. This works with most egg scattering fish as well.
  • Not really sexually dimorphic, females are slightly larger than males and when they are full of effs females tend to be a lot fuller and males are slimmer. With both in a tank it is noticable.
  • They could withstand just about any pH.
  • They are egg scatters and may eat their young and eggs.
  • They may eat anything it can catch and fit in their mouth, I fed them slow sinking pellet ground up and sometimes freeze dried blood worms.
  • They grow about 1.5 inches, depending on various conditions.
  • I'd recommend at least a 5 gallon for a group of 6.

fish_data.name: Goldfish
fish_data.comment:
I have kept Goldfish for many years and have even breed them. Goldfish are relatively large fish. Goldfish tend to be messy fish and create a lot of waste so powerful filtration should be used. Although some people have kept goldfish in small fish bowls, this is not a good practice as it will likely stunt their growth. Many people think goldfish are not hardy because they keep them in subpar conditions and they fish die quickly. There should be 0 Ammonia in the tank. If the fish do not last 5 years or more then you probably are doing something wrong.
  • Not really sexually dimorphic, females are slightly larger than males and when they are in breeding condition the males might develop white pimples on their gills and pectoral fins.
  • Most will adapt to just about any pH, but a pH of 7.0 would be good.
  • They are egg scatters and will eat their young and eggs.
  • They may eat anything it can catch and fit in their mouth, I fed them Tetra Color sinking granules.
  • They grow about over 5 inches, depending on various conditions and what type, they could get to be 10 inches or more from head to tail.
  • I'd recommend at least 30 gallons for the first fish, another 20 gallons for a second fish, and then after that 10-20 gallons for each additional fish.
